I am not a big fan of superfluous commenting, and wouldn't like to see a comment with every dependency that does not provide additional information not already obvious.
An example of a good comment (as I see it) could be something like with the JUnit vintage engine (indication of the reason a certain dependency was added).
An example of a reasonable comment (matter of style) could be an explanation about a group of related dependencies (main disadvantage being that this is hard to keep correct) like the OSGP dependencies.
As we don't have conventions for this, you could leave the comment here if you think it makes things more clear, or remove it if you agree it is a bit too much commenting individual dependencies by name.

nodes.bodyText: Some improper camel casing. I am not sure how much was already there and if any was introduced here, but abbreviations like OSLP or UID should be camel-cased like Oslp and Uid and not in all upper-case letters.
I will refactor all to getDeviceUid
I am not sure how much was already there --> most of it was already there ;-)

It either makes sense or does not make sense to have both the device identification and the device UID as parameters to a method like this, depending on whether my understanding about the device UID is correct.
I thought the device UID would always be the bytes of the device identification, encoded as a base-64 string (in code Base64.encodeBase64String(deviceIdentification.getBytes(StandardCharsets.US_ASCII)) as it is applied in the DeviceConverter of osgp-adapter-ws-publiclighting).
If that understanding of mine is indeed correct, we should only ever specify both device identification and device UID as inputs if we would want to check handling of unmatched values (according to the relation described before).
In all other cases we can derive one from the other, and for readability probably just talk about the device identification in the steps.
As I don't think this idea I am having is applied in our current test base, we maybe should check both if it is correct, and if so, whether it would be good to start applying it from here at this moment.

As how things are build in our cucumber test set your statement is not true. (I am not saying that you are wrong, but that's not how the cucumber test are set up)
The default device_uid as set in PlatformDefaults.java = dGVzdDEyMzQ1Njc4. That decodes to test12345678
The default device_identifcation as set in PlatformDefaults.java = TD01
So in the tests device_uid and device_identifacation are not coupled in any way. If we do want to couple them, that will likely requires changes in many tests. I did not look into that. I also wa not aware of the (pretented) relatation between device_uid and device_identification.
For now, I will suggest to keep the fields unrelated. Maybe it should be another issue on the back log.
What do you think?

Agreed it would probably have too much impact to do something about the device identification vs UID split to make the tests simpler (if the assumptions hold up we can regard the relation between the two as fixed).
Any reason to document the deviceIdentification and not document the other params?
No, I guess this is old code. There are, unfortunately, many flaws in the Java documentation. I can have a look at this case.

I just checked. All methods that have 'protocol' as a parameter, are missing this comment. Ugly, but not really related to this issue. Let's adapt it together with the new issue on the backlog about the protocol parameter.
Checked... This is a particularly bad case. The method has 3 parameters of which 2 are not used. (Changed the doc)

I am not sure how much sense it makes that these methods have a protocol in the form of a parameter,
Its value does not appear to be used, and the protocol is always OSLP here.
Would it perhaps be better to remove the parameter and hard code OSLP in a get configuration \"([^\"]*)\" message?

Agree with you on that. I had this discussion before with Kevin. I already proposed to remove all these unused parameters. Removing all these protocol parameters should in my opionion be a new story on the back log.

The remarks about the documentation of params, proper camel-casing. the device UID vs device identification and the usefulness of the protocol parameter appear to apply to some more of the (refactored) methods.
I think it would be good to consistently apply changes (or ignore the suggestion when there is a good reason) to all these methods, but I won't repeat the identical comments throughout this file.

This probably works for now, but I don't have a good feeling by just making op a device UID for mocking the device interaction.
An - I think - more robust way to deal with it, would be to add the device identification in the step line in the feature file.
If there ever will be any scenario with multiple devices of which one but not the others is to work in the specified way, this could lead to trouble.

The TODO above this refactored line does not make sense anymore, as there is no ByteString.EMPTY left here.
At the place where it is left, it should be resolved, as we shouldn't leave TODOs in the code like this.
If there is no way to get clarity about this, and we think it is not really important, I'd remove the "TODO: " and just leave a comment that there might come a time when we would use more interesting values, but that the empty value will do for now.
If we cannot get the clarity now, but we think we really need this, I guess it should be managed via the backlog and not by having a TODO in the code.
Removed the TODO

Assigning to parameters, though not harmful here, wouldn't be a coding practice I would encourage.
Maybe nicer to just return the default DEVICE_UID instead, or drop the null-check (as it is a private method it should be easy enough to enforce this, and if not we will immediately see failing tests).

Regarding just returning the default device UID, that is not what it does. More precisely, that is not what the line a commented on does, it is what the method does, but that wasn't my point.
What it does, is producing some return value by assigning to a parameter (bad practice), which causes a side effect later-on.
The method is rather short, so it is not that hard to comprehend, and you can leave it as is if you like it better this way.

Oh, agreed, thanks for pointing out. It can potentially hide an unwanted edge case (cq bug) where settings == null
I'll remove the null check since it is/should not be needed anyway.

This works just fine, but it looks like the result is already available from computeIfAbsent, and could be returned from the previous line, without looking it up again.

The use of the ConcurrentMap for the OSLP messages suggests this class is set up for safe use in a multi-threaded environment.
This makes me wonder if it is OK not to guard the sequence number against possible multi-threading related issues,
If there is reason to be careful about threading, accessing the value should not be thread-unsafe. This would mean to synchronize reads or writes to the sequenceNumber or change it from Integer to AtomicInteger.

Good point, but in this case, I don't think it really is an issue. There is only one class from where the sequencenumber is retrieved or changed, and that is from MockOslpChannelHandler. There is only one instance of that class, and that's not shared over threads.
The fact that ConcurrentMaps are used, is because there is a mock server thread, and a 'cucumber' thread. The cucumber thread adds mocks to the map, and the mock server removes them.

It's not really easy to find a nice name here, but I don't like the choice for getFromMap as it does not tell anything about the methods intent, only that it deals with a map. Maybe something like getNextMessage?
Hmm, indeed, the name is unclear. I changed it to pollMessage. Since that's what is does. It polls the queue (picks up first item and removes it from the queue)

This looks OK, yet the message may be a little low on useful information.
What I mean is that you would have to look at the stack trace to see whether a request has not been received or a mock response has not been set up.
So the information is there, but it could be made more "in your face" which might help getting faster to the right solution if this exception is found in the test logs,
If you think it is clear enough as it is, you can leave it like this.

As these are fairly simple one-liners I could live with the small duplication here, but you could consider doing the same thing as with getFromMap (getNextMessage) but here it would be addNextMessage, and for the has-responses methods there could be hasNextMessage (would also bring some symmetry and make the internal mini API of queueing and retrieving messages a little more obvious).
You might even abstract all the map and queue details by putting them in a new class like MessageBuffer (or some better name) of which you would have one for the requests and one for the responses.
Use your own judgement if you agree this would improve things, or if you think it will be fine enough as it is.
I go with you for getNextMessage, but not with addNextMessage. Because when you add a message, getNextMessage can return a different message. I changed the getters to poll

Ha, I had considered something with poll as a suggestion but rejected it because I felt it was too much about a non-essential implementation aspect. I am OK if you stick with the poll-based naming though, as I think it isn't a very clear cut case which is better.
Regarding getNext/addNext something similar applies. I just did not think of a next at the same position. Probably my thinking in this case was more linked to the queue implementation, where you get the next from one end, and add the next to the other. Same as with the other, I'll leave it up to you to decide what you want the code to end up with.
I guess so ;-) thanks

I like that here the deviceIdentification is used as the key, but this is confusing, because when I look at the call sites, the input used appears to be a deviceUid.
The nicest would probably be to use the identification everywhere, but at least (whichever it will end up to be) it would be good to name it consistently, and not mix this up as both the deviceIdentification and the deviceUid exist (and have a related but distinct text value).
Thanks, changed it
Better access the static method in a static way, and not through this (seen at multiple locations in this class).

Don't leave commented out code as part of the class,
If the sequence number does not need to be updated here, just remove it.

Is this debug statement a lie? (I assume the sequence number from the message on the channel is not necessarily the same as the sequence number from the device state that is printed out - though it would be if the commented out code were uncommented.)
No need to have a double empty line before and after the line setting the messageType.

Not from your changes, but this comment looks stale and misleading. The sequence number is not passed to handleRequest as the comment says. Better remove the comment I guess as the sequence number is still used, but in another manner.
(I am not a big fan of these comments even if they would be correct, as they seem to offer little beyond what can be read from the code itself. And if the code changes without the comment that describes it, it just becomes confusing.)

Hmm, I had a look. What the code actually does it at first glance not really clear. The handleRequest(message) does increment the sequence number, but there are no checks in relation to the incoming message.
I removed the comments
Not from this pull request, but shouldn't this be "Sent" instead of "Send" (I would assume that would be fair to think given the await just before)?
Indeed

This will probably work, but I am a bit confused finding the scenario context in the DeviceState.
I haven't looked into it enough to have a clear picture, but I could imagine an alternative where the specific increment is calculated outside of this class and provided as input to incrementSequenceNumber(int amount) (or something like that) instead. This could be added leaving the no-arg call with an increment of 1 and the call with the amount as an option for code that knows about increment amounts.

To be honest, I just copied this whole method from (I thought the handler), and didn't change anything. It wasn't really clear to me what all exactly it should to, so I left it unaffected. I'll have a look if I can refactor the method.

OK, just see what quick improvements you could do, if any, With some code being moved around (which is fine) I did not see immediately what was new, and what was "inherited" from whoever worked on it before.
This looks unnecessary. If next is bigger than SEQUENCE_NUMBER_MAXIMUM, then sequenceNumberMaximumCross would always be at least 1 given how it is calculated.
agreed

I see the code and what it does, but "cross" looks a bit unfamiliar to me.
Is it a logical name for what happens here?
Looks like a check for an overflow
The if statement looks like it always resolves to true and is unnecessary.
agreed
I haven't tried it out, but isn't this if-then-else with all its paths something that could be done more succinct with a modulo operation?
ProtocolSequenceNumber.feature covers tests where a negative increment is indeed possible.... The test does not cover edge cases. But for this reason I added the else again.
Probably best to remove this comment. It is not entirely accurate anymore, as it is now about something inside the device state, and the method name in itself looks clear enough.
Not sure what a "response requestMessage" means, and it feels like the code would be clearer without this comment.

Proper camel-casing would be getDeviceUid.

I don't know of a better method. The OSLP message is generated from protobuf definitions and they don't have this notion of message type I think. That would leave only the question if the method is at its place here, or if another location would make more sense.
Putting it into MessageType wouldn't be a nice option, since that is not OSLP specific, so it makes little sense to see the OSLP imports in there.
If we can't think of something, I don't think this should be left here as a TODO.
Is request a good name? If this is used (I haven't checked) for requests and responses then message may be more suitable.
Proper camel-casing would be deviceUid. (Also elsewhere in other added methods.)
I will refactor this
